title: 57-E
statement: E. Chesstime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutBrian the Rabbit adores chess. Not long ago he argued with Stewie the Rabbit that a knight is better than a king. To prove his point he tries to show that the knight is very fast but Stewie doesn't accept statements without evidence. He constructed an infinite chessboard for Brian, where he deleted several squares to add some more interest to the game. Brian only needs to count how many different board squares a knight standing on a square with coordinates of(0, 0)can reach in no more thankmoves. Naturally, it is forbidden to move to the deleted squares.Brian doesn't very much like exact sciences himself and is not acquainted with programming, that's why he will hardly be able to get ahead of Stewie who has already started solving the problem. Help Brian to solve the problem faster than Stewie.InputThe first line contains two integerskandn(0 ≤k≤ 1018, 0 ≤n≤ 440) which are correspondingly the maximal number of moves a knight can make and the number of deleted cells. Then follownlines, each giving the coordinates of a deleted square in the form(xi,yi)(|xi| ≤ 10, |yi| ≤ 10). All the numbers are integer, the deleted squares are different and it is guaranteed that the square(0, 0)is not deleted.Please, do not use%lldspecificator to read or write 64-bit integers in C++. It is preffered to usecin(also you may use%I64d).OutputYou must print the answer on a single line. As it can be rather long, you should print it modulo1000000007.ExamplesInput1 0Output9Input2 7-1 21 22 12 -11 -2-1 -2-2 -1Output9

processed.result:
Given a chessboard with some squares deleted, find the number of reachable squares a knight can visit starting from square $(0,0)$ in at most $k$ moves.  The knight's movement is restricted to the remaining valid squares.  

Input:

* Two integers $k$ and $n$: the maximum number of moves and the number of deleted squares, respectively.
* $n$ lines, each containing two integers $x_i$ and $y_i$, representing the coordinates of a deleted square.

Output:

* The number of reachable squares modulo $1000000007$.
Given a chessboard with some squares removed, count how many reachable squares a knight can visit starting from square (0,0) in a maximum of k moves.
